elements.text: Alphabet Cards of the first letter of each child’s name; a large paper with each initial, and art supplies for decorating letters, glue, decorated letter for your own name
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
? /f/ Another word that begins with /f/ is
. Let’s have some fun with our names!
In this activity, you will decorate the first letter in your name.
Display the Alphabet Cards for children to choose from.
Help children as they take turns identifying the first letter of their names. Have children trace the letter with their pointer finger.
Once all children have identified their letter, distribute the large letters you prepared for children to decorate.
My name begins with the sound /m/. What letter makes the /m/sound? Look at the letter that I decorated.
Do you know anyone else whose name begins with the same letter as yours? What other words might begin with this letter?
Support children as they decorate their letters.
Invite children to share their letters.
What letter does your name begin with? What is something you like that begins with the same letter?
Once the child shares, write the child’s whole name under their letter.

Some children may have difficulty identifying the letter that begins their name. Before using the Alphabet Cards, show them their names. Point to the first letter, and identify it. Then help them find the Alphabet Card.
Prepare some letters of children’s last names. Challenge children to decorate the first letter of their last name as well.
We all have first and last names. Our last names begin with a letter, too. What letter does your last name begin with?
Help Spanish speakers identify the cognates in the story: family/familia, reunion/reunión, moment/momento, baby/bebé, name/nombre.
For children who have difficulty working with glue, provide an array of stickers and tape to use for decoration. Assist children if they need help applying stickers or taping materials down.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Basket, ball, plastic hoop, and bean bag
Today we read Little Elliot, Big Family. Mouse wanted to solve Little Elliot’s problem and invited him to join his family reunion.
Remind children that they talked about ways to solve problems with friends.

Share with children that for this activity they will be working with partners. Each set of partners will take turns doing an activity. One partner will do the activity until her partner says, “Please, may I have a turn.”

Set up a walk on a straight line for one pair, a ball toss into a basket for another pair, and a beanbag toss into plastic hoop for another pair. Model the three activities with one of the children as your partner.
Have one child do an activity until her partner says, “Please, may I have a turn?” Continue until all three pairs have had turns at each of the activities.
While children are doing the activities, notice if they are having any conflicts, and if so how they are resolving them.

Guide children in a conversation about what it was like to do each activity and to wait to do each activity. Ask children to think about when they might say, “Please, may I have a turn?” at other times of the day at Pre-K.

If some children are not ready to work in pairs on their own, change the activity so that only one pair is engaged in the activity while the others watch. This will help to model what is expected. At some point, pairs may then be ready to work on their own at each activity.

After children suggest other times they may say, “Please, may I have a turn?” invite them to think of other ways to ask for a turn and have the children repeat them. For example, “May I have a turn now?” “I have been waiting, and I think it’s my turn.”

Invite multilingual learners to teach the other children how to say, “Please, may I have a turn?” in their home language. Take the opportunity to have English speaking children learn the expression and enjoy saying it.

Some children may find it difficult to wait for a turn and may impatiently ask for their turn without giving their partners enough time. To help them wait, give them a small sand timer or a number to count to, before they ask for their turn.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Art supplies, drawing paper, a drawing of your family to share
We saw different families doing different activities. We asked and answered questions to help us better understand the story.
In this activity, you will make Elliot part of your own family!
Draw a picture of your family doing a fun activity. Make sure you include Elliot in the fun!
You can use markers and other art materials.
My family and I like to go to the beach. Here is a picture of my family enjoying a beach day with Elliot.
What activity is your family and Elliot enjoying? When does your family do this activity?
If children struggle to think of activities they do with their families, guide them by asking:
What do you do on the weekend? Do you read together? Do you watch TV together?
Use the children’s pictures to discuss that families come in all different sizes. They are all different and they are all fantastic.
What is this Elliot doing with this family?
Are there any families that are doing the same activity?
Elliot is doing lots of different activities with so many different families. He is having fun with all of the families.
To limit the activity, ask children to just draw a picture of themselves with Elliot. Help them label the picture.
Challenge children to draw and label matching family members. For example, invite them to draw their grandmother and Mouse’s grandmother or their brother and Mouse’s brother.

As the multilingual learners in your class speak about their drawings, invite them to use words from their home language. Ask them to tell how they would invite Elliot to come to their house in their home language.
Provide images or examples of other families doing activities. Review these activities with the children.
What is the family doing? Which family members do you see?
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Premade “picture frames” made of stickers or printed borders on paper; art supplies
We had fun acting out parts of the story and talking about families.
In this activity, you will make pictures of different members in Mouse’s family.
In the beginning and at the end of the book, we see different members of Mouse’s family in picture frames. Pictures like these are called portraits.
Today, you will choose one of Mouse’s family members to draw.
Who is it? What is the family member doing in the picture?
Draw one of Mouse’s family members.
This is Mouse’s grandmother. She is making cheese chowder.
As you watch children involved in the creative process, comment and ask questions:
Which family member are you drawing? What is he doing? What is he wearing?
Invite children to present and share their portrait with the class. Talk about why it’s fun to do things with family members.
For this activity, help children by drawing two circles for them to use to complete their mouse body and head. Suggest the features to add–eyes, ears, nose, mouth, arms, legs, and tail.

Challenge the children to name the different members that could be in a family. List their suggestions and then read them together. Have children note the letters they know that begin any of the words.

For each multilingual learner in your class, provide family member names in both English and their home language. Have multilingual children share the words with their English-speaking classmates, who can try saying the word. This role reversal allows children to experience learning a language.

Provide mouse outlines to children with fine motor challenges. Have children decorate the outline by using stickers and other art supplies. Help children with application of stickers or other materials.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
